The Independent (UK), December 16, 'Nuclear power plants vulnerable to hacking attack in 'nightmare scenario', UN warns - Experts fear 'Fukushima-style' disaster as terrorists use new technology to attempt attacks': http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/nuclear-power-plants-vulnerable-hacking-attack-cyber-nightmare-united-nations-a7479546.html
Clips from article:
"Dr Patricia Lewis, Research Director of the International Security Department at Chatham House, told The Independent a cyber-attack on a nuclear power station was “a real risk”.  She said: “There’s an idea that the systems are protected…and that is a myth. Every system has vulnerabilities. We are seriously straying into what sounds like science fiction but isn’t. We are there now.”  She added: “This isn’t just imagined – this is already going on.” Several attacks on nuclear power plants have already taken place. In 2009 it was reported that an attack on an Iranian facility had hit its nuclear enrichment programme.  Plants in South Korea and Germany have also been subjects of cyber-attacks.  While these have been on a relatively small scale, a bigger attack could cause devastation. Dr Lewis warned the worst case cyber-attack could potentially cause “a Fukushima-style scenario” – a reference to the Japanese nuclear plant where three reactors went into meltdown in 2011 after tsunami damage.  She said: “It is probably beyond the capabilities of a non-state armed group but it may be very possible for a state to do that. Energy companies really need to understand the threat better [because] they don’t yet. There are things going on that we don’t fully understand.” Experts fear attacks targeted at nuclear power stations could be extended to nuclear weapons facilities. Dr Lewis said: “When it comes to nuclear weapons the consequences are far higher. Even if the probabilities are lower, the risk is huge.” Affirming forecast.

Reuters, December 1, 'FBI to gain expanded hacking powers as Senate effort to block fails': http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKBN13P2ER
Clips from article:
"Democratic Senator Ron Wyden attempted three times to delay the changes, which will take effect on Thursday and allow U.S. judges will be able to issue search warrants that give the FBI the authority to remotely access computers in any jurisdiction, potentially even overseas. His efforts were blocked by Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the Senate's second-ranking Republican.
The changes will allow judges to issue warrants in cases when a suspect uses anonymizing technology to conceal the location of his or her computer or for an investigation into a network of hacked or infected computers, such as a botnet.
Magistrate judges can currently only order searches within the jurisdiction of their court, which is typically limited to a few counties.
In a speech from the Senate floor, Wyden said that the changes to Rule 41 of the federal rules of criminal procedure amounted to "one of the biggest mistakes in surveillance policy in years."
The government will have "unprecedented authority to hack into Americans' personal phones, computers and other devices," Wyden said.
He added that such authority, which was approved by the Supreme Court in a private vote earlier this year, but was not subject to congressional approval, was especially troubling in the hands of an administration of President-elect Trump, a Republican who has "openly said he wants the power to hack his political opponents the same way Russia does."

The answer to this question seems to be very hard to define. Maybe it should just be cancelled. What counts as a "cyber attack"? What is "a nuclear facility"? I assume that malware that turned off a nuclear power station, or disrupted an uranium enrichment facility would count. But a laptop used by a student in a warehouse that stored nuclear medical material that got a virus that stole an Amazon password would not.  There must be thousands of places that use or research some kind of nuclear material, that could be called "nuclear facilities", but most of us would not call it that. A "cyber attack" sounds as if it means it was specifically targeted, but most malware is targeted at something. A "targeted attack" could be targeted at users of specific hardware, or software which could be specific to one facility or it could be targeted at duel use hardware or software. If attacks that took place before the question was set and those disclosed after it ends may or may not be excluded we end up with the answer being very fuzzy. I don't think we can forecast events where there is no clarity as whether they count or not.

There is definitely activity happening the cyber political domain, but it's focus is around the US elections and Russia's involvement in them. “Cyber threats are among top issues keeping energy leaders awake at night in Europe and North America,” said Christoph Frei, Secretary General, World Energy Council. “Over the past three years, we have seen a rapid change from zero awareness to headline presence. As a result, more than 30 countries have put in place ambitious cyber plans and strategies, considering cyber threats as a persistent risk to their economy. “What makes cyber threats so dangerous is that they can go unnoticed until the real damage is clear, from stolen data over power outages to destruction of physical assets and great financial loss. That said, human error is very often a key factor in the success of cyber-attacks, due to insufficient awareness of cyber risks among staff." Swift Banking Network Struggles With Wave of Cyberattacks
Gaps in security standards and poor communication about breaches have exposed vulnerabilities of the global money-transfer network
Banks rely on the network, formally called the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication, to guarantee the authenticity of orders to make payments from customers’ accounts. Hacking incidents at banks in Bangladesh, Vietnam and Ecuador have called that guarantee into question.
In each case, the attackers were able to obtain the banks’ Swift access codes and send authenticated but fraudulent requests to transfer funds. Swift wasn’t aware of the incidents in Vietnam or Ecuador until well after the attacks had taken place. Thieves stole $81 million from Bangladesh’s central bank in February and about $9 million from a lender in Ecuador last year.
More such incidents could emerge. Swift said in a note said it knew of recent fraud at a “small number” of customers. Cybersecurity firm FireEye Inc. said the thieves behind the Bangladesh attack appear to still be active. “We are seeing the same threat actors target some of our customers,” said Bryce Boland, chief technology officer for the Asia-Pacific region at FireEye. “I’m fairly confident other breaches are taking place.”

Here is some very good analysis published by Stratfor as  to the  the "inside attack scenario":  " See It’s important when considering insider cyber threats to not let the cyber element distract from the basic problem; hacking is still fundamentally theft of information. In fact, I would encourage security managers to think about these insider threats much as they would any other sort of corporate or government espionage.
Certainly, those looking to recruit an insider would love to have access to a systems administrator — essentially the corporate equivalent of an embassy communications officer. Systems administrators normally hold the keys to the kingdom, and in many cases they can access a variety of email accounts and other systems of interest to those conducting corporate espionage, whether they are motivated by ideology, looking to steal proprietary secrets or seeking information for insider trading purposes. That said, company IT staffs are not the only people who could be recruited to help carry out a cyberattack. In addition to the outright sale of a valid system login, as in the Apple example, insiders can also perform more subtle tasks to help hackers. One is to fill the role that an "access agent" would in traditional espionage: identifying potential sources. Rather than pinpointing and approaching individuals, in the cyber realm insiders can help hackers understand a company's systems and security procedures. They can also provide company organizational charts and examples of company communications. Perhaps more important, an insider has knowledge of who talks to whom and what topics they discuss; they may even pass along sample emails that show how people interact". This has turned into a battle about semantics. So a virus has been found at a nuclear facility in Germany (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-nuclearpower-cyber-germany-idUSKCN0XN2OS). It seems that my assumptions of governments wanting to keeping cyber attacks on the low were not based on reality. The big question right now is whether or not, this was a targeted cyber attack or whether it is a random virus. It had somehow crossed the air gap, because of infection through USB sticks. The jury is still out on this one, the important thing is to work out whether it was targeted or not, Or the chances that it was targeted or not. Some quotes from the article. "A nuclear power plant in Germany has been found to be infected with computer viruses, but they appear not to have posed a threat to the facility's operations because it is isolated from the Internet, the station's operator said on Tuesday." One question here is, would hackers try to implant viruses onto USB flash drives to get control into a nuclear facility knowing full well that even if the system was infected, it would still won't be activated because of the air gap? This is evidence that it may not have been targeted. So it brings up other questions, are nuclear facilities ever brought onto the internet? Or are software updates done via USB? Can you actually do damage to a nuclear facility if you don't have control over it once the virus has left your computer? How do people usually get viruses onto key USB devices? 1st question: no
2nd: unsure perhaps also via programming in an internal network?
3rd: yes, you can damage and corrupt files. 
4. Social Engineering. "The viruses, which include "W32.Ramnit" and "Conficker", were discovered at Gundremmingen's B unit in a computer system retrofitted in 2008 with data visualization software associated with equipment for moving nuclear fuel rods, RWE said." There were more than two types of virus, but the two mentioned at W32.Ramnit and Conficker. Where did they come from? When were they first detected? Is it likely that they are common around the world in 2008? I would not put too much emphasis on this because these are only two of the viruses found on the computer. The article seems to insinuate that the computer system was updated in 2008.  W32.Ramnit is mentioned in antivirus posts since 2010. I assume that it may have been created even before then. Conficker has been around since 2009. So I may believe that the cyber "breach" can be from the 2008 software update. But it may be equally likely that subsequent updates that haven't been made public have also introduced the malware. It seems unlikely that a nuclear plant could be running on the same software for nearly 8 years without a single software update. "Malware was also found on 18 removable data drives, mainly USB sticks, in office computers maintained separately from the plant's operating systems." The malware entered the office and the plant's operating systems. These USB sticks should have protocol that they never be used on both office computers and operating systems but we cannot assume that the protocol exists or was respected. Again, how do hackers usually infect USB drives? Is it difficult and requires an Ocean's 11 type of plan? Because the more difficult it is, the planning required, equals to less number of USB sticks infected and more likely that the hackers knew that the attack would not give them control if the plant is never on-line. But on the other hand, hackers may not be after control. They may just want to disrupt the systems but even so, if it was infected in 2008, and I'm assuming that was when the last major update was made, then the systems were not disrupted. However, if it was infected by an employee charging their phone on a port recently then this may not count as a cyber-attack either. If people set up the employee or if the employee themselves wanted to attack the plant, then that would constitute a cyber attack. I'm going to assume that cyber security procedures at the Gundremmingen are pretty lax. That it is somewhat easy to infect an employees phone by leaving a USB drive in the parking lot. That this can spread throughout the offices through plugging the USB into the system and plugging other USBs in as well.   Now I think it's time to crunch some numbers and remove some assumptions that I had before. One assumption that I wrote about previously was: "Do failed cyber attacks  count as attacks? Yes I believe so but in saying that I don't think they will be publicly disclosed because by releasing those details, nuclear operators risk people finding out about the security of these nuclear plants and they risk people becoming interested in cyber attacking nuclear facilities." However, malware has infected a critical system and it has not been successful. but the name of the nuclear plant has been published.  I previously wrote:
"I would place the possibility that a nuclear operator publicly discloses an attack at 1% of all cyber attacks on a guess." However, this rises a lot higher as operators are not afraid to release details and did so in this case. I would say that it should be 80 or 90%. Military cyberattacks from the US to Iran or from one country to another may seek to avoid this unless the damages needed to be publicly released. However, normal cyber attacks would be published.  So from last time, we calculated the chances of a cyber attack on a nuclear facility at 92%. The most important thing is calculating the chances of the breach being targeted aka cyberattack or just random malware floating around. This is really hard to figure out. A nuclear plant is an obvious target so there is a large chance that it was targeted and that some poor employee unknowingly inserted an infected drive into the system. On the other hand, random malware has got to be more common than targeted attacks. I can't find statistics online for the chances of cyberbreaches being targeted vs non-targeted. So I'm going to wash my hands and say 45% targeted and 55% non-targeted. For this specific case, I'm placing the chance at 45%. However, if it is found out that this was random malware floating around, then I'm going to assume that the match isn't quite over and that we're working from a fresh start. At which the probability becomes 0.92*0.95*0.45 = 0.39 Because we still don't know whether the Gundremmingen plant was targeted or not, I'm going to average out those two numbers: 0.42 or 42%.  My Brier score is going to be terrible either way. Unless I can figure out some hard tests on whether it is targeted or not.

@redacted I take your point that GJP doesn’t overly determine reliability of “definitions,” in the summaries of IFP’s and linked documentation and perhaps I have erroneously done so in the above comment. GJP does, however care about whether its IFP’s are falsifiable, and GJP has taken steps (particularly prospective ones when people aren’t yet claiming resolution) to clarify questions (see e.g. the question about Venezuela defaulting on debt which was recently updated to clarify that a restructuring of debt does not count). I think the @AndrewSabisky post in this thread (“background in the question… background context”) put it better than my use of the word “definitions” did. I don’t think GJP would take steps to provide background information and clarify background information if the context the background information provided was not highly relevant to creating a falsifiable IFP. I’d quibble with your rendering the first (but not only) substantive context for the word “cyber attack” in the Chatham report under discussion, which says “a …category of cyber attack [is] when a facility’s industrial control systems are disrupted”  as “cyber attack [upon] a facility’s industrial control systems” because the cyber attack does not need to be “upon” (your word) industrial control systems to be “on [a] nuclear facility” (language in the question stem) as described elsewhere in the report. If you ctrl f to the part of the report @clinton quoted about “the most basic attacks” two sentences earlier it says “there are a number of ways in which cyber attacks might affect nuclear facilities” which to my mind clarifies the “basic attacks” being talked about are forms of “cyber attacks” that “affect nuclear facilities”; for example, but not only, by “disrupting industrial control systems.” Agree with @morrell that I would be interested in any evidence of any other “basic attacks” affecting nuclear facilities in the timeframe of the question. A further reason that a “basic attack” seemed significant to the IFP resolution is because the Chatham Report proposed to create a framework for “promoting disclosure and information-sharing” among nuclear facilities about cyber attacks, while recognizing that nuclear facilities have “reluctance to disclose cyber attacks" that “stems partly from concerns for damage to reputation” (page x of Chatham Report exec summary). Thus, this incident seems significant to resolving the IFP because it could help show that efforts toward promoting public disclosure of incidents is working (Perhaps the fact that the Gunremmingen nuclear facility is slated to shut down eventually anyway mitigated such repetitional concern in deciding whether to make the disclosure?) Note that “publicly disclosed” appears in the question of the IFP. Zooming out a bit though, again it now really feels like my concerns are a bit myopically focused and to your point may have over-emphasized the Chatham Report. If I were in the shoes of the folks at GJP charged with resolving the question, I would probably need to defer to he experts themselves such as those at Chatham House (rather than close reading of the texts of their expert reports) to decide what qualified as a “cyber attack” for question resolution, and this incident is not exactly a blockbuster threat that helps those experts' cause of raising awareness to the same degree as, e.g., an indictment being unsealed that says hackers stole information that could be used to compromise a nuclear facility. The experts might lose credibility by  characterizing what turned out to be an otherwise uneventful publicly reported incidence of malware at a nuclear facility as a cyber attack (even in the event their report arguably did so, and even though if a person could be found to blame for the malware, I have little doubt a court could be convinced to characterize such incidence as a cyber attack on a nuclear facility). Lest that sound too cynical, I really do sympathize with the creators of the IFP at having to find the balance between a falsifiable and a ‘useful’ (know-it-when-you-see-it-happen that it was worth having forecasted it) on this topic. And their goals are noble; it's hard to imagine more important thing to better understand and raise awareness about than nuclear safety and security. In any event, it’s occurred to me that besides getting the attention of any question resolvers, my forecast of 100%'s probably not helping the ol’ Brier Score (sp?) if GJP's not going to affirmatively resolve based on this incident (in which case the 100% correct forecast would be irrelevant because I changed to 100% after the Gunremmingen story broke). Or unless a different incident occurs. So I'll change it. A Chatham House report (https://www.chathamhouse.org/sites/files/chathamhouse/field/field_document/20151005CyberSecurityNuclearBaylonBruntLivingstoneUpdate.pdf) referenced by and linked in the BBC article (http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-34423419) that the summary of this question links to uses the phrase "cyber attack" 63 times. As forecasters, we have to turn to the material given in the question/summary for definitions of what we are forecasting. The first substantive use/definition in the Chatham House report is: "This report... focuses on a... dangerous category of cyber attack – when a facility’s industrial control systems are disrupted or even captured and harnessed by saboteurs acting either inside or outside the facilities where these systems are located." Clearly the industrial control systems only need be disrupted, not captured and harnessed by sabateurs to qualify as a "cyber attack." Indeed a "cyber attack," on a "nuclear facility" according to the report, could be something that is not intended to "cause a dangerous incident.” Disruption seems to have been caused in the case of the In the case of the Gundremmingen nuclear facility malware incident under discussion in this thread; the facility was taken down to address the incident according to the english-language article @AndrewSabinsky circulated (http://www.techworm.net/2016/04/german-nuclear-power-plant-shut-due-malware-chernobyls-30th-anniversary.html). While this malware reportedly made it to “nuclear power plant’s Block B IT network that handles the fuel handling system,” (Id.) something so severe is not required by the report to qualify as a “cyber attack” on a “nuclear facility” but could only affect the business network of the nuclear facility: "Hacktivists... might carry out a cyber attack on a nuclear facility to raise awareness of vulnerabilities. Their goal is sabotage or disruption, so such attacks would be likely to involve defacements of websites or low-level attacks on the business network intended to embarrass an operator rather than cause a dangerous incident." According to the report, the attack could "affect nuclear facilities" while only targeting the "business networks belonging to owner operators." The report says: "Most attacks on these [business] networks will be aimed at the theft of confidential corporate data that can be used to garner  financial benefit." Others might be carried out for reconnaissance purposes, to steal operational information that can be used to conduct a more harmful attack at a later date." If the malware had to "steal operational information" in order to attempt to connect to the internet, it would seem to qualify under this broad definition, regardless of whether it attempted to target a nuclear facility specifically. I also don't buy the argument that we need to identify the actor and its intentions to call it a "cyber attack" under the report's definition; according to Kaspersky an expert affirmatively cited in the report, "victims of cyber attacks" could be accidentally infected (Kaspersky was referring to reported spread of Stuxnet to an unnamed nuclear power plant). To be clear, I am not necessarily advocating for such a broad construction of the definition of a "cyber attack"; but as a forecaster (rather than e.g. a judge deciding a point of law or an analyst writing reports that seek to raise awareness for cyber attacks), I feel I must use the definition given in the question I'm forecasting.  With that in mind, I vote 100%; a cyber attack occurred (100% now; I think I was above consensus but below the right side of probability at 30-something % when the Gundremmingen story broke). I'm interested in what others think (pushback? agreement?).

Note that cyber attack is different from cyber espionage.  Further note that the attack must be publicly disclosed. I've been thinking about how reluctant the nuclear industry is to reveal attacks because people don't understand nuclear power, and consequently can easily be made scared of it.  I'm reducing my forecast from 88 to 77%.

The paper Targetted Attacks Against the Energy Sector (Wueest, Symantec, 2014, http://www.symantec.com/content/en/us/enterprise/media/security_response/whitepapers/targeted_attacks_against_the_energy_sector.pdf) cites successful cyberattacks against nuclear facilities in 2001, 2003, and the 2010 disruption of the Iranian nuclear program by Stuxnet. Over the last 17 years, we've had 3 such disclosed attacks in these surveys, giving us a base rate of 17.6% and note that we have only 75% of the year left, giving us a nice base rate of 13.2%. For this to be true, we need three things to happen, firstly there must be an attack (successful or otherwise). Secondly, the attack must be detected, and finally, the decision to disclose must be taken. Regarding the probability of an attack, the SANS SCADA and Process Control Security Survey, 2013 (https://ics.sans.org/media/sans-scada-survey-2013.pdf) gives us quite a bit of detail. This survey finds that industrial supervisory control and data acquisition (ISCADA) systems are increasingly under attack, with 198 incidents reported the the US industrial control systems computer emergency team (ICS-CERT) in 2012. Further, this survey claims that ISCADA systems are "under increasing attack." 27.6% indicated that they had been, or that they suspected they had been, attacked. However, it would be nation-states with the capacity to do this successfully. Hacktivists and organised criminals probably won't try. Terrorists might give it a go, but they're very underfunded and underskilled in this area. Nation-states might want to avoid this kind of confrontation, as most countries systems are similar, so the chance of retribution is high. This points to an increasing likelihood of an attack, I'm going with 15.8% here. Moving on to the probability of detection, we those surveys seem show that there is a growing awareness of the security risks in the ISCADA area. They should be improving their capabilities, and therefore improving the likelihood of detection. It is, however, a truism that attacks only improve, and that attackers have a natural advantage. These might actually reduce the likelihood of detection. Hard to say all in. Maybe a slight increase, as older, successful attacks maybe discovered by better inspection techniques. Bump to 16.8% Finally, regarding disclosure by the end of the year. This need not be the victim themselves, many hacktivist and terrorist groups will disclose the attack to claim responsibility. However, there's also "low level" threats, like the garden-variety malware and ransomware that affect normal people. These are unlikely to be reported and dealt with in the course of business. So it would have to be a relatively high-impact attack for the disclosure to happen -- no one's going to care that Bob's machine down in accounting was infected with ransomware! What they would care about is it spreading to the significant parts of the organisation. Hard to call this one. Maybe put it back down around 15.8%? So overall, 16% seems to be a relatively sensible estimate. https://www.thalesgroup.com/sites/default/files/asset/document/thales-cyber-security-for-scada-systems.pdf is also another relatively useful source, but it's more marketing rather than investigation.

Starting out at the lowest level. Something like this requires great technological expertise combined with a terrorist ideology. It is an unlikely combination for any one given year. However, the security vulnerability cited in the links are real, and such an attack will surely eventually happen if steps are not taken to forestall the eventuality.

Analysis
The questions that should be asked is how many cyber attacks on nuclear facilities have there been?
What are nuclear facilities? Are these power-plants? Weapons Complexes? Stockpiles?
I'm assuming its all three. If a nuclear facility has been hit by a cyber attack, will they publicly disclose this information? Will governments release information regarding hacked nuclear facilities? Do governments release details on nuclear facilities that have problems? How many nuclear facilities have problems? Do failed cyber attacks  count as attacks?
Yes I believe so but in saying that I don't think they will be publicly disclosed because by releasing those details, nuclear operators risk people finding out about the security of these nuclear plants and they risk people becoming interested in cyber attacking nuclear facilities. Olympic Games was only found out by the public during a leak because Stuxnet was actually uploaded to the internet.
Do attacks on non-operating nuclear power plants count?
I would say that this is a definition question, it would only matter if there were dangerous nuclear material around, but there are incentives for nuclear operators to not release this information. Unless it had significant risk of damaging the environment, e.g. if people have to be relocated. I assume that attacks on nuclear facilities, failed or successful will not be publicly disclosed by the nuclear operators unless it is a leak, or it endangers personnel and residents close by to the point where they will need to be relocated. A crisis situation. However, I believe that it is difficult for hackers to reach into critical system components as it has not been done on a power generating nuclear facility. I would place the possibility that a nuclear operator publicly discloses an attack at 1% of all cyberattacks on a guess. It's possibly smaller. However, hackers who have been successful are more likely to publicly disclose their attacks for political reasons or personal reasons. This release of information cannot be stopped by governmental powers after it has been leaked. I would place the possibility of a successful nuclear hacker publicly disclosing their attack at 20% on a guess. It may be larger.  Many nuclear facilities are not weapons facilities but rather are power plants. So what is the percentage of nuclear facilities weapons and what are for power? I would believe that it is far more easy and more common that power plants are infected. What is the number of power facilities and utility facilities that are nuclear?
The Nuclear Energy Initiaive places this at 340 (without counting US). Their source is from  the International Atomic Energy Agency PRIS Database.
The number in the US is 61 plants but 99 reactors according to the US Energy Information administration. There are 7304 operational power plants in the US. So a total of 401 around the world. How many power and utility facilities have been cyber attacked?
Department of Homeland Security with ICS-CERT, says that there have been 198 cyber attack incidents in 2012. 41% of total incidents were in energy sector. 15% were on water sector.   But we assume this number has been increasing every year. So number of attacks on energy plants in 2012 were 81. This includes all energy producing facilities as well as nuclear. So the chances of it being a nuclear plant out of all power generators is 61/70304 is 0.000867.
The number of attacks on a nuclear facility is estimated to be 0.000867*81 = 0.07. So 7% of a nuclear facility being attacked expected per year. Increase say 20% (I feel that this is conservative) of cyber attacks per year since 2012 then we have  7% *1.2*1.2*1.2*1.2 = 14% of a nuclear facility being attacked in the US per year. The US accounts for 61/401 nuclear plants in the world, 15%. So around the world you may expect 0.92 of a nuclear plant being attacked every year. You can even round it up to 1 nuclear plant being expected to be cyber attacked every year. This is an expected number and if the question finished here, I would put the probability very high but it publicly disclosed. According to Amano Director General of the IAEA "Reports of actual or attempted cyberattacks are now virtually a daily occurrence,” Mr. Amano affirmed, warning that the nuclear industry had not been immune from the global threat. “Last year alone, there were cases of random malware-based attacks at nuclear power plants and of such facilities being specifically targeted.” So we have reason to suspect that nuclear facilities around the world have an attack on them each day. This sounds frightening and alarming but his statement was very broad, it includes all malware attacks, some random and some specifically targeted every day. So assume that there are at least 365 incidents of attacks on nuclear facilities. Of these, I'm going to give 20 to be targeted which seems fairly large given the amount of random malware floating around. These may or may not be successful by the way. So around 20/365 about 5% being targeted. Non-specificed such as random email hacks are assumed to not be publicly disclosed. Specified is a different story. So with this new information, I'm putting it at 5% for now.  But I'm sure that failed specified cyberattacks will never become publicly disclosed. Successful specified cyber attacks disclosed by the hackers has a large chance of being disclosed but by the nuclear operators a lower chance. But I'll leave that for tomorrow.

Russia has considerable incentive to attempt this in Ukraine, where, critically, the government would also have an incentive to disclose it.  Attacks on Western powers are possible, but as stated by others unlikely to be disclosed (but this is not at all certain - if sanctions are needed in response the attack will need to be avowed).  I note that most state-led cyber attacks on western critical infrastructure facilities so far have been to gain data rather than DoS :  data is still a relevant target from nuclear facilities, but the incentive to attack in order to denigrate is much lower unless we are in a real cold war, which reduces the chances.  On the other hand, we are now in a world where lots of state-led "cold" activity does in fact end up being declared by target country:  russian jets off coastline, attacks on dissidents in western countries, chinese-led cyber attacks - because it has generally become both harder to cover up information from a powerful press and more expedient politically to disclose.   Attacks on North Korean facilities seem one of the more likely outcomes to that particular problem - being a solution that might minimise military escalation.  One assumes this would remain undeclared, but then again any successful attack might need to be avowed by perpetrator (China/US?) in order to take heat off South Korea and any physical response resulting.   All this needs to be tempered by capability/chance of success, even if the intent is there to try it (and the motivation there to disclose it).   I go: 15% chance of Russia doing this successfully in Ukraine and a 90% chance of disclosure = 13.5%
10% chance of any state doing it to any western country, with 30% chance of disclosure = 3%
12% chance of this being done (successfully) to N Korea (from maybe a 40% chance of attempt) with a 50% chance of disclosure = 6%
8% chance of a non state anarchist organisation managing this somewhere in world but with low (10%) chance of disclosure as no response to need to justify: 1%
= 23%

I'm going to dig into this more, but its tricky - the public disclosure versus the actual attack itself. Nitro Zeus wasn't launched, - but was disclosed, which makes me question it since its now featured in a documentary, and feels like a cautionary tale more than a post-event analysis - like the Stuxnet attack.
Here's my 'straw man plan':
- Number of nuclear facilities operational by country, with MWe Net
- Existing conflicts between top nation-states with the greatest # of operable facilities and MWe.
- Type of cyber attack - Zero Day/SCADA vulnerability - how these are introduced into the facilities & the time it takes to execute: example: Stuxnet took years to develop, but now the blueprint for it exists in the open.
- Development of cyber defense post Stuxnet that would counter these attacks
- How are attacks reported out publicly - by what means?
My assumption is that an attack capable of dismantling a nuclear facility would take time to develop, then would take time to implement post-Stuxnet, and the subsequent publicly acknowledged disclosure of this would be contested and guarded against so I'm initially predicting a low probability for before the end of 2016.  After 2016 and around other power/water plants that have more open SCADA vulnerabilities, and could be attacked by a smaller effort is more concerning.

U.S. Had Cyberattack Plan if Iran Nuclear Dispute Led to Conflict 
" 
The plan, code-named Nitro Zeus, was devised to disable Iran’s air defenses, communications systems and crucial parts of its power grid, and was shelved, at least for the foreseeable future, after the nuclear deal struck between Iran and six other nations last summer was fulfilled. 
... 
Nitro Zeus was part of an effort to assure President Obama that he had alternatives, short of a full-scale war, if Iran lashed out at the United States or its allies in the region. At its height, officials say, the planning for Nitro Zeus involved thousands of American military and intelligence personnel, spending tens of millions of dollars and placing electronic implants in Iranian computer networks to “prepare the battlefield,” in the parlance of the Pentagon. 
... 
The Snowden documents revealed a series of technologies that can be used to insert programs remotely in a system disconnected from the Internet. " -- Update:  It occurs to me that not everyone thinks about modern cyber attacks everyday so I'll add this. One does not acquire vulnerabilities from god.  That a zero day attack was planned means an attack took place. The Stuxnet virus required years to create the intended result because it's a conventional in that it was a virus. This use of zero day attack is unlike other conventional virus cyber attacks because the vulnerability was exploited for diplomatic leverage.  By analogy, Rene Decart said essentially, "I doubt, therefore I think, therefore I am."  Similarly, to plan a zero day attack, means there was an attack to identify the vulnerability, therefore an attack occurred.  One does not acquire vulnerabilities from god. --
furthermost to claim an attack didn't occur would be like using the defense:  "I broke into his home with the intent of killing him but he wasn't home so I'm not guilty." You broke into the guys home so the charge won't be murder 1 but it's still a crime whether one fails to achieve the ultimate intent or not.  Cyber attacks are a process, as seen in this case.  The intent of the attacks were to stop Iranian nuclear development not indiscriminate killing & mayhem -- that's called terrorism. --
And in the case someone thinks this is technical mumbo-jumbo, let's take a really simple example:

What Specific Measures Are in Place to Protect Safety?        Nuclear Energy Institute   April  2015 Each U.S. nuclear power plant has taken the following measures to ensure protection against cyber threats:
•	Isolated key control systems using either air gaps, which do not implement any network or Internet connectivity, or installed robust hardware-based isolation devices that separate front-office computers from the control system, thus making the front-office computers useless for attacking essential systems. As a result, key safety, security and power generation equipment at the plants are protected from any network-based cyber attacks originating outside the plant.
•	Enhanced and implemented strict controls over the use of portable media and equipment. Where devices like thumb drives, compact disks and laptops are used to interface with plant equipment, measures are in place to minimize the cyber threat. These measures include authorizing use of portable assets to the performance of a specific task, minimizing the movement from less secure assets to more secure assets, and virus scanning. As a result, nuclear power plants are well-protected from attacks like Stuxnet, which was propagated through the use of portable media.
•	Heightened defenses against an insider threat. Training and insider mitigation programs have been enhanced to include cyber attributes. Individuals who work with digital plant equipment are subject to increased security screening, cyber security training and behavioral observation.
•	Implemented cyber security controls to protect equipment deemed most essential for the protection of public health and safety.
•	Taken measures to maintain effective cyber protection measures. These measures include maintaining equipment listed in the plant configuration management program and ensuring changes to the equipment are performed in a controlled manner. A cyber security impact analysis is performed before making changes to relevant equipment. The effectiveness of cyber security controls is periodically assessed, and enhancements are made where necessary. Vulnerability assessments are performed to ensure that the cyber security posture of the equipment is maintained.

To put these number's into a context:
As of July 2015, 30 countries worldwide are operating 438 nuclear reactors for electricity generation and 67 new nuclear plants are under construction in 15 countries.  For me the 438 reactors pose less than a 1% chance of Stuxnet level attack and public disclosure (it would have had to been planned years ago). The 67 new sites are VERY likely targets.  long term:
Not in using cyber to disrupt or damage the facility now but to penetrate, reconnoiter, monitor, zero-day-attack, create a vulnerability, etc. what will occur once these facilities are operations. These are long term attacks (i.e. watchdog groups, anti-nuclear zealots, state sponsored attacks, etc.).   Meaning a "cyber attack" won't be malicious code to effect harm this year but will be integrated into systems or integrate itself into code to create a benefit later.  It's therefore FAR more likely to be detected as the systems are built, integrated, checked, checked again, stress tested and certified, rechecked under different circumstance.  Strategies like creating a honey pot that looks like an attack that's intended to be found will hide the actual attack as a diversion, maybe it's built into the design and only detected when there's another problem, so the possible scenarios go on and on and on and on.  Main point - long term cyber attack more likely found during construction. short term:
The question says "nuclear facilities" which is MUCH broader than the number of reactors. This could include storage, transport, waste sites (i.e. were a Terrorist would target).  And, it also include construction of facilities of current sites and design/planning for future nuclear facilities sites (i.e. where state sponsored cyber attacks would target).  Targeting an existing, hardened, and operating nuclear reactor would be the least likely target of any critical infrastructure given that so many alternatives like the power grid, transport or storage facility in obscure countries, and simple scrapping and surveillance for a good vulnerability are FAR more likely given the chance of success.  Private companies have NO interest to publicly disclose:
In reading the articles and reports cited have a different objective than this question here as they're directed more at the private sector moving forward.  (1) They're looking at critical infrastructure postures of PRIVATE facilities to cyber security moving forward, (2) The lack of open design and international standard to govern/inspect PRIVATE developments of critical infrastructure against cyber security moving forward, (3) the entire process of design, construction, and operation need to be taken apart and re-thought if future cyber vulnerabilities are going to be accounted for.  There are concerns with Public facilities but covered by the fact that cyber defenses and security measures are probably secret and shouldn't be public (as stated in the articles) but the concern is Private companies working in the nuclear field and their posture to cyber security. I believe this a question is vague and that "cyber attacks" occur on a daily basis.  As a grad student in Cyber Security I'm not impressed by the catchall term when Stuxnet is certainly a perturbation from something benign like a software update malfunction. Vulnerability cuts both ways and can be self-inflicted as much as externally attacked.  I interpret this question as to leave open a benign mistake such as happened in the U.S. state of Georgia (2008).  That's fundamentally different than an external malicious attack.  Two publicized cyber attacks were internal accidents from updates that triggered safety procedures leading to shutdowns.  Hearsay about unauthorized internet connections and potential SCAD entry points are very unlikely to be found, exploited, NOTICED, and reported within a year given that Nuclear facilities FEAR of this known threat and thus UNWILLINGNESS to publicize a breach that is consequential to security because it's kinda alarmist.   Lack of incentive to publicizing actual attacks that produce harm/scrutiny and heightened incentives to publicize extremely minor incident where they "saved the day" to procure funding or bolster claims to be combating the threats make this question more chance than substance.  So a "legitimate external malicious attack" there is 10-20% chance in my mind of an attack as sophisticated as Stuxnet to demonstrate capability by a foreign actor.  But the possibility of a benign mistake of a self-inflicted vulnerability makes this closer to chance than a question of calculated malicious intent.  Absent language or a word that the attack is an "explicit eternal cyber attack to cause harm, disruption, or surveillance" I'm moving over 30% then I think this question warrants given it's purpose, which makes it look as though it's a much larger threat than I believe it is.

I'm less interested in whether there will be cyber attacks, and am more concerned with whether those attacks will be publicly disclosed. Stuxnet and its target the Iranian Nuclear Weapons Program were only discovered/disclosed because the worm spread so voraciously. That kind of spreading is either a desperation-driven mistake (unlikely) or a subtle demonstration of capability and intent to those who might interfere with the interests of the attackers. (Source: Countdown to Zero Day). Demonstration for demonstration's sake by the United States (one of the likely attackers in the Stuxnet case) is unlikely to happen again, because the demonstration of intent and capability already happened with Stuxnet. A repeat of that magnitude is unlikely to be necessary in the next year because smaller-scale and more subtle warnings/attacks are more appropriate for the level of tension that I see in the public media right now for non-Iranian programs (that is, no tension at all). That being said, a more repeat or more extreme attack on the Iranian program might be appropriate if they are found to be in violation of the newly signed treaty. Let's put that likelihood at 6% because while the Iranians are likely to try to cheat on that deal, they will likely take more than a year to find ways to do so with the appropriate level of discretion. An attack in response to that cheating does not count as a demonstration attack, because the shot across the bow already happened. It would be an attack in earnest, and would likely be more destructive than Stuxnet was. They only way that I see another demonstration happening is if another power develops a cyber capability with stuxnet level of sophistication and needs to prove it to the wider world. A major element of that sophistication was having access to configuration details of the nuclear facility, something that requires an extremely high level of reconnaissance. China has an active cyber offensive program. Russia has the remnants of the KGB laying around, and safe havens for criminal hackers. They (and other nation-states) are likely working on responses to Stuxnet, but it is unclear if they will chose nuclear non-proliferation as their highest priority on which to demonstrate their capability. (They might opt for the power-grid instead, for example). I'm putting the chance of them developing and demonstrating the capability in a tit-for-tat fashion within the next year at 15%. If find the likelihood of a desperation-driven mistake causing massive propagation of a worm to be very low, given the kind of sophistication that would need to go into an attack that targets such a critical piece of national strategy. That kind of a mistake would be more likely if the attack were unsuccessful, but verifying that an unsuccessful, widely propagating attack were actually targeting nuclear facilities would be a difficult case to make, and I'm not sure who would *want* to make that kind of a case. Exposing an unsuccessful attack would make the attacker would seem incompetent, and the defenders would be demonstrating fear (unless the attackers were identifiable and embarrassable) and escalating the issue. That being said, the chance of the disclosure of an unsuccessful attack should be non-zero, so let's call it 3%. Summary:
-> US follow-up attack on Iran 6%
-> Non-US demonstration 15%
-> Accidental disclosure 0%
-> Disclosure of unsuccessful attack 3%

As per this particular site: http://www.hackmageddon.com/2016/01/11/2015-cyber-attacks-statistics/ there are some interesting statistics. First, there were an average of 84.5 cyber attacks per month in 2015 and 73.3 in 2014 which was a 15% increase.  If we assume another 15% increase, that comes out to 97 attacks per month or 1166 per year. The site also breaks down the motivation behind the attacks.  I made the assumption that attacking a nuclear facility will be either hacktivism cyber espionage or warfare (combined 12.2%) or what I estimated to be a small fraction of potential hacktivism (1% out of the total 20.8%).  This means that around 13.2% of the attacks per year will be potentially motivated to attack a nuclear facility: ~153 attacks per year.  From the 2014 data (the classification for utilities is missing for 2015 data) there is a 3.8% rate of attacking utilities which would yield an expected 6 attacks per year. So, of these 6 per year, we want to figure out what the likelihood is that one will be against a nuclear facility. There are 437 current civil reactors online, and hand waving up to 500 including government reactors around the world.  There are around 96000 power plants worldwide.  If the attacks were at random, this means 6 * 500 / 96000 = ~3.125%
However, I believe that due to their symbolic importance, the likelihood is significantly higher that an attack will be attempted (assuming 10x) for 31% Given the successful attack on Israel's electric grid recently, I would estimate that there risk of any attack on a nuclear facility is roughly doubled (citation needed) giving me a base of around 62% http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3419426/Hackers-cripple-Israel-s-electricity-grid-cyber-attack-just-temperatures-drop-country.html

Based on comments by @mos, I revisited my forecast for this question. The Chatham House source (source 8) that cites 50 attacks is very interesting. A few things to consider with regard to the specific statements regarding this source in the report. First, it is an estimate. Second, it is an estimate by an unnamed source. The source is identified in the notes as a “A US industrial control systems expert who was trained as a nuclear engineer.”  Third, there is no time parameter with respect to the estimated attacks. Have these additional 45 or so attacks taken place since 1992, 2002, 2012? 
Some idea as to the recent frequencies would help with understanding the trends. Of course, the reason we don’t have this information is because the attacks were not made public and verified.  There is another source (source 3) who makes similar remarks about the number of attacks. Source 3 is identified as “A senior technical officer working on control computers at a Canadian owner-operator of nuclear power plants.”  From Chatham House Report
(Source 3): 
“All of the examples in an IAEA training course that I give are the same two or three instances from 2003 and 2008 at a few plants. It looks like we are picking on these plants, but it is just that they are the only ones that have ever disclosed breaches and, therefore, that we can talk about. I am sure that there have been many more.” (Source 3) (pg.15) While only a few cyber attacks on nuclear facilities have been made public, one estimate (Source 8) puts the number of major incidents that have affected industrial control systems as high as 50 (this is in addition to frequent routine attacks on business networks):  “What people keep saying is ‘wait until something big happens, then we’ll take it seriously’. But the problem is that we have already had a lot of very big things happen. There have probably been about 50 actual control systems cyber incidents in the nuclear industry so far, but only two or three have been made public.” (pg.15) Although I don’t feel confident in the number expressed by source 8 (50), I was nevertheless going to use the number as a baseline to formulate a new forecast. I felt that I might be prejudiced against revision, so thought the exercise would be useful. Since no time parameter was provided, I’m was going to use 1992 as the starting year and 2015 as the end year (24 years, 50 attacks, 5 of which went public and were verified as cybersecurity issues).   So, in the first 23 years, 10% of the 50 incidents went public. (this assumes that all 50 incidents were cybersecurity issues). A straight average = 2.17 incidents per year for 23 years. I started to set this up as a weighted average over this period, with more weight to the last 16 years (2000 forward). But the time period is the main problem here in terms of the distribution of the incidents. Plotting some subjective assessments for probability is one thing, but assigning 50 potential incidents arbitrarily to a 23-year period is another. You would then have to weight and distribute these numbers on a trend line. After some consideration, I felt my initial forecast should be adjusted upward to accommodate for estimated incidents. However, running the weighted forecasts and trending for the next year did not seem necessary.  It is likely that the majority of the incidents occurred over the last 15 years. I’m only dealing with what we know…what is public and confirmed in the media and intelligence community. I define “publicly” in this question as an incident reported in well-established media outlets and confirmed by the source of the attack. I don’t know any other way to read “publicly” in regards to such an incident.  The one issue that might arise is the possibility of a regime like North Korea claiming an attack from some source with no means to verify the claim outside of what the regime reports. That scenario requires some thought from the good folks at GJP.  It is true that the majority of incidents that are public occurred within the last 15 years. (Stuxnet and the South Korean facility within the last 6 years.)  Given that the report indicates an increasing likelihood of more attacks on an industry largely unprepared for them, I am going to adjust my forecast slightly.   New Forecast: 66% Thanks to @mos for reminding me of the additional incidents cited in the report. I did gloss over that part in my initial assessment.

Knowing that an attack would undermine civilian nuclear energy a lifelong scholar that is working in a civilian nuclear energy program would be unwilling to participate in that attack. The question derives from the warnings of one report. According to the report, over the last 24 years there have been seven incidents at nuclear facilities (1992, 2003, 2006, 2008, 2010 (2), 2014).  Of the seven, two are not cybersecurity issues related to sabotage. So, that leaves five over 24 years. Three of the five occurred in the last 5 years. So, the trend for attacks on nuclear facilities appears to be ramping up. The most recent incident involved allegations by South Korea that North Korea hacked one of their facilities.  The possibility of cyberattack includes just about every institution. The interesting thing about this report is that by publicly announcing these vulnerabilities, it likely alerts would-be hackers to the opportunities. This is not relevant to how I assess the question…just a related thought.   For a state to execute an attack of this nature against another state is no small thing. It is clear that corporate espionage, governmental espionage, and hacking into other institutions is going to be the norm for states. But an attack on a nuclear facility is another matter altogether. The stuxnet attack was likely a joint operation between the U.S. and Israel against Iran. Stuxent also appears to have reached a Russian facility in the same period (one of the three attacks in the last 5 years). The need for such an attack against Iran does not currently exist (at least as far as the U.S. is concerned) based on the recent nuclear deal. Of course, other rivals of Iran could attempt similar attacks for their own reasons. One can conjure up any number of scenarios for a state to decide to undertake such an attack. But again, the blowback from being discovered may outweigh perceived benefits. Russia vs. Ukraine, Saudi Arabia vs. Iran, Israel vs. Iran, U.S. vs North Korea, North Korea vs. South Korea, etc. If one condenses the stuxnet attack to include both Iran and Russia, then you have 2 incidents in the last 13 years.  Despite the numbers, the likelihood of an attack rises above 50% based on the events related to North Korea alone. In addition, the probability of another attack between other states is not zero. Finally, we have the ever present hacker community – non-state actors who might attempt something – again not zero.  Current forecast: +58% - State to State attack

Cyber attacks on critical infrastructure are routine, near daily events, so it is likely there have already been cyber attacks on nuclear facilities.  The issue, however, is whether the authorities (DHS, NRC, DOE, utility officials, local and federal law enforcement) would publicly disclose that an attack, even a failed attack, had occurred.  There would be nothing to be gained for the authorities from publicly disclosing that a failed attack had occurred.  If, however, a cyber attack succeeded in some fashion, then public disclosure would be more likely since disclosure would contribute to answering the public's questions about why there was some sort of failure or irregularity at the nuke plant in the first place.  Since it is unlikely that there will be a successful cyber attack on a nuclear facility then it is relatively unlikely that any cyber attack would be disclosed.
